author: By Julie Turkewitz and Simon Romero
title: Murder Mystery: What Were Colombian Military Vets Doing in Haiti?
description: At least 20 Colombians have been implicated by Haitian officials in the plot to assassinate the president. But their role in the killing, if any, is murky.
content: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — One evening in early June, Mauricio Javier Romero, a decorated 20-year veteran of the Colombian military, received a call from an old army buddy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anahad O'Connor
title: Can Marijuana Make You a Better Athlete?
description: When Sha’Carri Richardson was denied a spot in the Tokyo Olympics after testing positive for marijuana, it reignited a debate about using cannabis to aid in sports. Does it actually help?
content: Josiah Hesse, a journalist who lives in Colorado, never voluntarily exercised a day in his life until he turned 30, when he decided to start doing it for health reasons. But right away, he hated working out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Musa Okwonga
title: In the Big Euro 2020 Game, I Knew the England I Was Rooting For
description: Who really represents the country?
content: BERLIN — It is an odd thing, to watch your country of birth from afar. Having been in Germany for seven years, I sometimes feel the connection to England with an even greater intensity than I did when I was living there. I find myself being more passionate about its politics — and, of course, its football.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: What is Virgin Galactic’s space plane, and what did it do?
description: The V.S.S. Unity is making its fourth trip to space.
content: The rocket plane, a type called SpaceShipTwo, is about the size of an executive jet. In addition to the two pilots, there can be up to four people in the cabin. The particular SpaceShipTwo that flew on Sunday is named V.S.S. Unity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Ritchie
title: Q&A: Siya Kolisi on Rugby, Race and What’s Next for South Africa
description: As South Africa’s rugby team prepares to host the British and Irish Lions, we talk to Siya Kolisi, the team’s first Black captain, about the Springboks and growing up in a poor township.
content: South Africa’s national rugby union team, the Springboks, won the World Cup back on Nov. 2, 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Henry Parham, Who Fought in a Black Unit on D-Day, Dies at 99
description: He helped tell the story of the 320th Battalion, gaining recognition only late in his life. “I did what I was supposed to do as an American,” he said.
content: The story of D-Day, the Allied invasion of Normandy on June 6, 1944, has been told and retold through books, movies and the recollections of soldiers, sailors and airmen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: A message said to be from the president’s widow is posted to Twitter.
description: An audio recording claimed to be of Martine Moïse, who was wounded in the attack that killed her husband, urged people to carry on his “battle.” But doubts were raised about the clip’s authenticity.
content: An audio recording said to be of Martine Moïse, the widow of President Jovenel Moïse of Haiti, has urged people to carry on his “battle” in a country long plagued by gang violence and now plunged into a deep institutional crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The teams have arrived, so find a TV. Here’s how to watch England-Italy.
description: Sunday’s final at London’s Wembley Stadium is being broadcast in the United States by ESPN and Univision, and via their ESPN+ and TUDN streaming platforms. But, of course, many Times readers are not in the United States.
content: Sunday’s final at London’s Wembley Stadium is being broadcast in the United States by ESPN and Univision, and via their ESPN+ and TUDN streaming platforms. But, of course, many Times readers are not in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alanis Thames
title: Sean O’Malley hit Kris Moutinho with flurries upon flurries.
description: An exciting first bout of the U.F.C. 264 main card ended with fan favorite Sean O’Malley getting a technical knockout over Kris Moutinho in Las Vegas.
content: An exciting first bout of the U.F.C. 264 main card ended with fan favorite Sean O’Malley getting a technical knockout over Kris Moutinho in Las Vegas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: Euro 2020’s top scorer is the own goal.
description: The battle for the Golden Boot, awarded to the tournament’s top scorer, will be decided today, and the England forwards Harry Kane (four goals) and Raheem Sterling (three) seem to be the only two players left with a realistic chance to catch the current leaders, Patrick Schick and Cristiano Ronaldo, who both scored five before departing Euro 2020.
content: The battle for the Golden Boot, awarded to the tournament’s top scorer, will be decided today, and the England forwards Harry Kane (four goals) and Raheem Sterling (three) seem to be the only two players left with a realistic chance to catch the current leaders, Patrick Schick and Cristiano Ronaldo, who both scored five before departing Euro 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Branson Completes Virgin Galactic Flight, Aiming to Open Up Space Tourism
description: The successful trip was the first in a series to the edge of space and beyond by billionaire entrepreneurs that seek to make human spaceflight more routine.
content: SPACEPORT AMERICA, N.M. — Soaring more than 50 miles into the hot, glaringly bright skies above New Mexico, Richard Branson at last fulfilled a dream that took decades to realize: He can now call himself an astronaut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter and Oscar Lopez
title: Haitians decry photos said to be of President Moïse’s corpse circulating on social media.
description: A country already reeling from the assassination of its leader reacted to the images with horror and despair.
content: The photos are horrifying. They seem to portray the body of President Jovenel Moïse of Haiti laid out in the morgue, his left eye crushed in, the flesh of one of his arms torn by bullets, his mouth gaping.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia Heyward
title: ‘Lord, Hear Me’: Residents in Florida Condos Fear They Could be Next
description: A deadly condo collapse in Florida has prompted a close look at other buildings.  A luxury tower in Bal Harbour was deemed safe by an inspector but is spending $4.5 million in restoration.
content: BAL HARBOUR, Fla. — The condo complex at the exclusive address of Bal Harbour 101 in South Florida feels more like a luxury hotel than somebody’s home. At the entrance, residents are greeted by a marble fountain and a valet. Inside is a private restaurant. The balconies upstairs offer panoramic ocean views.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Extra time: It was never going to be easy.
description: Tweet! Tweeeeeet! That’s it for the first extra period.
content: Tweet! Tweeeeeet! That’s it for the first extra period.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: At Wimbledon, Novak Djokovic Sends a Message Impossible to Ignore
description: Djokovic, now with 20 career Grand Slam titles, suggested that the three-way tie with Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal could be broken at the U.S. Open.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — The Big Three now have 20 apiece.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt and Liz Day
title: Prominent Lawyer in Discussions to Represent Britney Spears
description: Mathew Rosengart, a former federal prosecutor, plans to attend a hearing on Wednesday and make the case that the singer should be permitted to hire him for her conservatorship battle.
content: A prominent Hollywood lawyer has had discussions in recent days with Britney Spears about representing her in her conservatorship battle, and he plans to attend a hearing in Los Angeles on Wednesday to begin the process of taking over as her counsel, according to a person briefed on the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Janet Yellen Warns That Coronavirus Variants Threaten Global Recovery
description: At the end of a gathering of the finance ministers of the Group of 20 nations, the U.S. Treasury secretary called for an acceleration of vaccine distribution worldwide.
content: VENICE — Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen said on Sunday that she was concerned that coronavirus variants could derail the global economic recovery and called for an urgent push to deploy vaccines more rapidly around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Short on vaccines, Asia grapples with Delta-driven outbreaks.
description: Across the region, everyday activities are again being restricted even as the West edges back to normalcy.
content: In recent days, Indonesia has reported nearly twice as many coronavirus cases as the United States. Malaysia’s per capita caseload is roughly on par with those of Brazil and Iran. And the latest Covid surges in Japan and South Korea have prompted harsh new restrictions on movement there, effective Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu
title: Despite Outbreaks Among Unvaccinated, Fox News Hosts Smear Shots
description: Months after Rupert Murdoch got a Covid-19 dose, one of his network’s stars, Tucker Carlson, called a Biden vaccination proposal “the greatest scandal in my lifetime.”
content: Back in December, before the queen of England and the president-elect of the United States had their turns, the media mogul Rupert Murdoch received a dose of a Covid-19 vaccine. Afterward, he urged everyone else to get it, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: A Day Filled With Noise, and a Silence They’ll Never Forget
description: A Euro 2020 delayed by the pandemic and then extended to a shootout ends, finally, with an Italian celebration on the field and stunned fans in the stands.
content: LONDON — All day, there had been noise. The songs had started early in the morning, as the first few hundred fans appeared on Wembley Way, flags fluttering from their backs. They had echoed through the afternoon, as first tens and then a hundred thousand more had joined them, as shattered glass crunched underfoot.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Came Across a Guy Who Was Sitting on the Curb With a Guitar’
description: A Clash singalong, running an errand before the big fight and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Voters Chose Boring Over Bombast. They Got Biden’s Penchant for Pontificating.
description: Even the president labeled a speech boring recently, an admission that highlights a tendency toward delivering minutiae-filled discourse over scaling oratorical heights.
content: CRYSTAL LAKE, Ill. — Even President Biden thought he had been ponderous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: In a 100-Mile Race That Demands Both Physical and Mental Fortitude, Women Set the Pace
description: Ultramarathons may be the ultimate endurance leveling ground. Half of the top 30 finishers at this year’s Western States 100-mile race were women.
content: Beth Pascall did not know what was happening behind her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Who were the crew members aboard the flight?
description: Along with Mr. Branson, three crew and two pilots are aboard the Unity.
content: The pilots are David Mackay and Michael Masucci.
source.name: The New York Times

title: We go to penalties at Wembley.
description: Italy wins Euro 2020, extending England’s wait for a major championship.
content: Italy is in a tight huddle and England is a looser one as their coaching staff pick their penalty takers. But the tension ahead of the shootout is palpable. All that work, and it comes down to this.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Tai Tuivasa knocked out Greg Hardy then pounded beers.
description: Tuivasa won in the first round.
content: For just a few seconds Greg Hardy had an advantage. Sensing blood in the water, he advanced on Tai Tuivasa. But he did not sense Tuivasa’s left fist, and just over a minute into the first round it dropped Hardy to the canvas, and the fight was over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Dueling Claims to Power. Broken Institutions. How Does Haiti Fix This?
description: Other countries have faced similar challenges, often with poor results, from protracted limbo to, in the worst cases, civil war.
content: PARIS — Battered by gang violence and corruption, its Parliament near vacant, its judiciary in tatters, its Constitution subject to dispute, its poverty crushing and its history a chronicle of unrest, Haiti was in bad shape even before its president was assassinated and rival factions laid claim to power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: With Conor McGregor Injured, U.F.C. Faces Big Challenges
description: His star power is enormous. But after breaking his leg in a fight on Saturday, the sport must bank on other athletes.
content: LAS VEGAS — As Conor McGregor waited inside the octagon for Dustin Poirier to enter, he bounced around, looking fluid, fresh and agile.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman
title: Fauci says boosters are not recommended ‘right now’ and reiterates school reopening guidance.
description: Dr. Anthony Fauci said federal agencies were conducting independent research on the potential need for vaccine boosters.
content: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci made the rounds of the morning TV news shows on Sunday, trying to quell confusion over the latest federal pandemic guidance for the start of school in the fall as well as growing questions about the necessity of booster shots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: A number of breath-based coronavirus tests are in development around the world.
description: “It’s clear now, I think, that you can detect this disease with a breath test,” said one scientist.
content: Scientists have long been interested in creating portable devices that can quickly and painlessly screen a person for disease simply by taking a whiff of their breath. But delivering on this dream has proved to be a challenge. Different diseases may cause similar breath changes. Diet can affect the chemicals someone exhales, as can smoking and alcohol consumption, potentially complicating disease detection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Williamson
title: How Did Allison Highwolf Die? Distrust Fuels a Mystery in Indian Country.
description: When a Northern Cheyenne family questioned their daughter’s untimely death, official indifference deepened their pain — and their suspicions.
content: NORTHERN CHEYENNE RESERVATION, Mont. — The knock on the door came at 3 a.m., when Pauline Highwolf opened it to see a police officer from the Bureau of Indian Affairs. “Don’t tell me,” she said, backing away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brandon Yu
title: Katie Kitamura and the Cognitive Dissonance of Being Alive Right Now
description: Her new novel, “Intimacies,” introduces readers to the perceptive, digressive mind of an interpreter at The Hague who is dealing with loss, an uncertain relationship and an insecure world.
content: Not long after her father died, Katie Kitamura remembers hearing Charles Taylor speak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Montgomery
title: After Marathon Hearings, Texas Republicans Advance Voting Measure
description: A Republican-backed bill to overhaul the state’s voting system cleared two key committees in the Legislature on Sunday after a marathon session of testimony in the House that lasted nearly 24 hours.
content: AUSTIN, Texas — Texas Republicans moved legislation to overhaul the state’s voting system closer to passage on Sunday, brushing aside fierce opposition from Democrats to gain approval from key committees in the House and the Senate after marathon weekend hearings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter
title: Haiti’s police chief suggested a Florida-based doctor arrested in the president’s killing was plotting to assume the presidency.
description: The suspect is now the third with U.S. ties to be held in the assassination of Haiti’s president.
content: A Haitian-born doctor based in Florida has been arrested as a “central” suspect in the assassination of President Jovenel Moïse, and the national police chief suggested at a Sunday news conference that he believes the suspect was plotting to become president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: Nigeria Wins Historic Upset Over Team U.S.A. in Olympic Exhibition
description: Nigeria defeated a roster stacked with All-N.B.A. players on Saturday, becoming the first African team to beat the U.S. men’s national team.
content: The U.S. men’s basketball team was upset by Nigeria on Saturday evening in its first exhibition game ahead of the Tokyo Olympics, a stunning outcome even if the effects are more symbolic than likely to affect the United States’ eventual gold medal hopes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: More Prep, More Readers: When Journalists Go on the Air
description: Appearing on TV news shows lets Times reporters take their work to a wider audience. But the opportunities must be handled with care.
content: “What do you think?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Haiti hurtles toward a constitutional crisis.
content: Since the assassination of President Jovenel Moïse last week, political chaos has gripped Haiti. On Sunday, the country hurtled toward a constitutional crisis, as its top leaders both jockeyed for control.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: When is Jeff Bezos’ flight, and how is it different?
description: On July 20, another billionaire is scheduled to take another rocket to the edge of space. Jeff Bezos, the founder of Amazon, founded his rocket company, Blue Origin, with a vision of millions of people living and working in space in the future.
content: On July 20, another billionaire is scheduled to take another rocket to the edge of space. Jeff Bezos, the founder of Amazon, founded his rocket company, Blue Origin, with a vision of millions of people living and working in space in the future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: Why did Richard Branson take this risk?
description: Virgin Galactic is one among a long line of flashy upstart businesses promoted by the English entrepreneur.
content: Founding a space exploration company was perhaps an unsurprising step for Mr. Branson, who has made a career — and a fortune estimated at $6 billion — building flashy upstart businesses that he promotes with a showman’s flair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia Heyward
title: Bootleg Fire in Oregon Scorches 143,000 Acres as Heat Wave Continues in the West
description: With record-breaking temperatures and hard-to-contain wildfires, Western states are struggling through a hellish summer.
content: As the West continues to bake under torrid temperatures, an out-of-control wildfire burned across southwest Oregon on Sunday, scorching more than 143,000 acres, threatening the power grid that connects Oregon and California and driving people from their homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Soccer Success Is Making England ‘Whole Again’
description: The stunning rise of England’s soccer team is helping define a new vision of Englishness, putting the lie to those who would stir culture wars.
content: LONDON — Lee Anderson will not be watching the match. He has not seen so much as a minute of England’s progress through this summer’s European soccer championship. He missed the drab, underwhelming early games, the thrilling, cathartic victory against Germany, the smooth dismissal of Ukraine and the gripping, tortuous defeat of Denmark.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar
title: One Village Quelled the Virus. The Next Was Overrun. It’s a Bad Sign for India.
description: The uneven response to India’s catastrophic second wave, coupled with widespread vaccine hesitancy, indicates that the coronavirus is here to stay.
content: GARH MUKTESHWAR, India — When a devastating second wave of Covid-19 infections reached India’s countryside this spring, the village of Khilwai took immediate action. Two testing centers were set up, and 30 positive cases were isolated. The outbreak was contained with just three deaths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Short and Stout
description: Kevin Christian gives us a geography lesson.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Surprise! Rachel Fabi, your intrepid Monday-to-Wednesday columnist, is off the grid in more ways than one this week, so other members of the growing Wordplay posse will be sitting in for her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: The Bucks Have Big-Time Supporters: Kareem and Oscar Robertson
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and Oscar Robertson were the top two scorers on Milwaukee’s 1971 title team. They’re rooting for Giannis Antetokounmpo to win it all this year.
content: The Milwaukee Bucks’ only title came in 1971, when they swept the Baltimore Bullets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: ‘We Don’t Need Another Michelangelo’: In Italy, It’s Robots’ Turn to Sculpt
description: Using the same marble found in Renaissance masterpieces, a team of robots is accepting commissions. Their owners say tech is essential to Italy’s artistic future.
content: CARRARA, Italy — For centuries, the massive marble quarries above the Tuscan town of Carrara have yielded the raw material for the polished masterpieces of Italian sculptors like Michelangelo, Canova, Bernini and, most recently, ABB2.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Christopher Jones
title: ‘I Can’t See Myself Doing Anything Else’
description: In California, a young generation of Sikh farmers has agricultural roots that stretch back 900 years.
content: KERMAN, Calif. — Simranjit Singh is a second-generation American farmer, but his agricultural roots go back 900 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles
title: Cubans Denounce ‘Misery’ in Biggest Protests in Decades
description: The rallies, widely viewed as astonishing for a country that limits dissent, were set off by economic crises worsened by the pandemic.
content: MIAMI — Shouting “Freedom” and other anti-government slogans, hundreds of Cubans took to the streets in cities around the country on Sunday to protest food and medicine shortages, in a remarkable eruption of discontent not seen in nearly 30 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: The leader of Haiti’s Senate is among those vying for power.
description: Joseph Lambert has been backed by a group of lawmakers and a coalition of parties to become the country’s provisional president.
content: Just days after the assassination of President Jovenel Moïse of Haiti, a high-stakes battle for control of the country is heating up, and the president of the Senate, Joseph Lambert, is among those jockeying for power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Conor McGregor appeared to break a bone at the end of Round 1.
description: Dustin Poirier won via a doctor’s stoppage when McGregor was unable to report for the second round.
content: Conor McGregor lost his rematch against Dustin Poirier after a bizarre end to the first round in which McGregor appeared to break either his lower left leg or his ankle. As McGregor and Poirier swung at each other, McGregor stumbled backward and broke a bone without Poirier hitting him.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Local Guerrilla Fighters Routed Ethiopia’s Powerful Army
description: A scrappy force of local Tigrayan recruits scored a cascade of battlefield victories against the Ethiopian military, one of Africa’s strongest. Times journalists witnessed the decisive week in an eight-month civil war.
content: SAMRE, Ethiopia — The Tigrayan fighters whooped, whistled and pointed excitedly to a puff of smoke in the sky, where an Ethiopian military cargo plane trundling over the village minutes earlier had been struck by a missile.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: New Zealand, where Covid-19 is dormant, fights another respiratory virus, and other news from around the world.
description: The country’s lockdowns to keep the coronavirus at bay may have helped spur an outbreak of a flulike illness in children.
content: Strict lockdowns in New Zealand last year appear to have contributed to a recent outbreak in children of respiratory syncytial virus, or R.S.V., a highly contagious, flulike illness whose symptoms include a runny nose, coughing, sneezing and fever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘Black Widow’ Star David Harbour Loves Being a Big-Screen Loser
description: The actor talks about his roles as a failed superhero in the new Marvel blockbuster and as a milquetoast accountant in Steven Soderbergh’s “No Sudden Move.”
content: This article contains spoilers for the films “Black Widow” and “No Sudden Move.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: A Black American Designer Disrupts the French Couture
description: Kerby Jean-Raymond of Pyer Moss reinvents the oldest form of French fashion with politics, humor and a Black Panther.
content: Villa Lewaro, the Palladian estate built in Irvington, N.Y., by Madam C.J. Walker, a child of slaves who became a beauty mogul and the first female self-made millionaire in the United States, is pretty far, geographically speaking, from Paris — about 3,605 miles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: Weapons Cache Seized at Denver Hotel Near Stadium Hosting All-Star Game
description: The F.B.I. said it did not believe the episode was connected to terrorism, but the police were still investigating why four people who were arrested were in a downtown Denver hotel.
content: The police in Denver seized 16 long guns, body armor and more than 1,000 rounds of ammunition on Friday at a hotel about two blocks from the stadium where the Major League Baseball All-Star Game is to be played this week, according to officials and local reports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Will home-field advantage be the difference (again) today?
description: As fans filled the streets outside Wembley again on Sunday ahead of the Euro 2020 final, it is worth remembering that it was not by chance that all four semifinalists — England, Italy, Spain and Denmark — played all three of their group games at home, reducing the amount of time and energy they might have lost to travel over the course of the monthlong championship.
content: As fans filled the streets outside Wembley again on Sunday ahead of the Euro 2020 final, it is worth remembering that it was not by chance that all four semifinalists — England, Italy, Spain and Denmark — played all three of their group games at home, reducing the amount of time and energy they might have lost to travel over the course of the monthlong championship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Haiti, G20, Euro 2020: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: Far from Europe, another cathartic victory.
description: England vs. Italy is not the only major final this weekend.
content: England vs. Italy is not the only major final this weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: What do we really know about Harry Kane?
description: There are a lot of things that everybody knows about Harry Kane. There is the fact that he is the captain of England’s national soccer team, a status that bestows upon its bearer the sort of profile unavailable to most athletes, particularly in tournament years. It is part-of-the-furniture fame, royal family fame. Everyone has heard of Harry Kane.
content: There are a lot of things that everybody knows about Harry Kane. There is the fact that he is the captain of England’s national soccer team, a status that bestows upon its bearer the sort of profile unavailable to most athletes, particularly in tournament years. It is part-of-the-furniture fame, royal family fame. Everyone has heard of Harry Kane.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter, Eric Nagourney and Julian Barnes
title: Third Man With U.S. Ties Has Been Arrested in Haiti Assassination
description: The U.S. said it was sending a team of investigators to help the Haitians, but it is treading lightly, avoiding any role in keeping order despite a request for military forces.
content: The Haitian authorities said Sunday they were holding a Florida-based doctor they believed had aspirations of seizing power in his native country in the assassination of President Jovenel Moïse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Barkevious Mingo, N.F.L. Veteran, Charged With Child Sex Crime
description: Texas police arrested Mingo as part of their investigation into an act alleged to have taken place in 2019.
content: Barkevious Mingo, an eight-year N.F.L. veteran, was arrested in Arlington, Texas, on Thursday night and charged with indecency involving sexual contact with a minor, a felony.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: Iranians, desperate for Covid vaccines, are crossing into Armenia to get them.
description: Iran’s daily caseload has been rising, and only 2 percent of its population is fully vaccinated.
content: Thousands of Iranians frustrated with the government’s chaotic vaccine rollout and desperate for protection after enduring wave after wave of the coronavirus are flocking by air and land to neighboring Armenia to be vaccinated against Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: Lionel Messi and Argentina Beat Brazil in Copa América Final
description: A star player’s glittering career finally gets the one honor it was missing: a major title with his national team.
content: Lionel Messi finally ticked the last empty box in his glittering soccer career on Saturday night, leading Argentina past host Brazil, 1-0, in the final of the Copa América in Rio de Janeiro.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn, Clifford Krauss and Tamir Kalifa
title: More Power Lines or Rooftop Solar Panels: The Fight Over Energy’s Future
description: The president and energy companies want new transmission lines to carry electricity from solar and wind farms. Some environmentalists and homeowners are pushing for smaller, more local systems.
content: The nation is facing once in a generation choices about how energy ought to be delivered to homes, businesses and electric cars — decisions that could shape the course of climate change and determine how the United States copes with wildfires, heat waves and other extreme weather linked to global warming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: M.L.B.’s Top Prospects Are Busy Again
description: Last year, the pandemic canceled the minor league season. Now, those lower leagues are testing grounds for new rules. And two key events, the Futures Game and the draft, have kicked off All-Star weekend.
content: DENVER — When the call came for Spencer Torkelson, he was at home in California, locked down like everyone else. His college baseball season at Arizona State had ended abruptly because of the coronavirus pandemic, so he was free of distractions when the Detroit Tigers selected him first overall in the draft in June 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Consider gado-gado, ground lamb pulao or sheet-pan baked feta.
content: Good morning. It’d be nice to steer into the worlds of tiny houses, #vanlife and trail cooking. But I’d want a lot of cooking equipment, too, which complicates matters: a smoker and a 60-inch grill, say, along with a propane hob cooker; a discada; a 110-quart cooler filled with pellet ice. I’d want shovels for clambakes, a rotisserie, a Schwenker and absolutely a wood-burning pizza oven on a trailer to haul behind the van or the house, depending. So this remains a pipe dream.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: The intensity and awkwardness leaves a window for Poirier and McGregor to fight again.
description: Dana White, the U.F.C. president, said Conor McGregor would have surgery on his left leg on Sunday.
content: Conor McGregor said he would walk Dustin Poirier “around the octagon like a dog.” Instead, he laid next to the cage with a cadre of medics attending to him while the referee, Herb Dean, raised Poirier’s left hand in victory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Morris
title: ‘You Just Feel Like Nothing’: California to Pay Sterilization Victims
description: More than 20,000 people, many of them disabled, poor or people of color, were forced to undergo the procedure under the state’s decades-long eugenics program.
content: Leonard Bisel was 15 when the state of California decided that he should not have children, threatening to lock him up and force him to do hard labor if he did not submit to sterilization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alanis Thames
title: Max Griffin closed the preliminary bouts with a win over Carlos Condit.
description: In possibly the biggest fight of his career, the welterweight Max Griffin beat Carlos Condit via unanimous decision with a dominant first round in which he landed a series of clean leg kicks.
content: In possibly the biggest fight of his career, the welterweight Max Griffin beat Carlos Condit via unanimous decision with a dominant first round in which he landed a series of clean leg kicks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: Why Do English Soccer Fans Sing ‘Sweet Caroline’?
description: At Wembley Stadium, where London has been following in the footsteps of Belfast and Boston, good times never seemed so good (so good, so good, so good).
content: After a tough year for London — and a tough 55 years for fans of England’s men’s soccer team — the city’s Wembley Stadium is roaring again, and the fans are singing an American song.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Pope Francis Leads Sunday Prayer a Week After Surgery
description: Francis made his first public appearance since the operation, greeting the faithful gathered in the courtyard of Rome’s Gemelli hospital, his voice appearing weak at times.
content: ROME — Pope Francis on Sunday made his first public appearance since undergoing colon surgery last week, greeting the faithful from a balcony at Gemelli hospital in Rome.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and Alexandra E. Petri
title: Behind Zaila Avant-garde’s Win, a History of Struggle for Black Spellers
description: Before Zaila became the first Black American to win the Scripps National Spelling Bee, other Black students faced decades of discrimination and doubts about their abilities.
content: In 1936, MacNolia Cox, a 13-year-old girl from Akron, Ohio, made it to the final round of the National Spelling Bee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kelley Manley
title: Should a Mental Health Emergency Derail a Dangerous Climb?
description: A mountain climber with bipolar disorder had an episode that thwarted his team’s plan to summit the world’s seventh-highest peak, prompting a debate about mental illness in adventure sports.
content: Cory Richards was about to attempt an unclimbed route up the seventh-highest mountain in the world when he realized he needed to stop before he started.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: ‘Mother, When Will You Come?’
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, July 11, 2021.
content: “My mother kept us safe like an umbrella does, from the heat and rain of life.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Gutierrez and Jes Aznar
title: Overwhelmed by Chinese Fleets, Filipino Fishermen ‘Protest and Adapt’
description: Beijing’s aggression in the South China Sea has harmed the fishermen’s livelihood for years, and now the lessons of Scarborough Shoal are playing out elsewhere in the disputed waters.
content: MASINLOC, the Philippines — The fishermen along the western coast of Luzon Island, in the Philippines, have known for generations that the seas, the tides and the weather can determine their fortunes. More recently, they have added China to that list.
source.name: The New York Times

title: From The Sunday Read Archives: ‘Alone at Sea’
description: How one man completed a third trans-Atlantic kayak trip just shy of his 71st birthday.
content: For Aleksander Doba, pitting himself against the wide-open sea — storms, sunstroke, monotony, hunger and loneliness — was a way to feel alive in old age. Today, listen to the story of a man who paddled toward the existential crisis that is life and crossed the Atlantic alone in a kayak. Three times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: 5 Pieces of Good News About the News
description: A look at some of the ventures that have sprung up, fueled by a new sense of mission in American journalism and by the sheer quantities of money available.
content: My great predecessor in this column, David Carr, wrote at a time when the conventional wisdom was that the internet was destroying journalism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $800,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: Two Are Killed in Arizona Firefighting Plane Crash
description: The plane was engaged in aerial reconnaissance over the Cedar Basin fire when it crashed on Saturday, the Bureau of Land Management said.
content: Two people who were helping to fight a wildfire in western Arizona died on Saturday when their plane crashed, the Bureau of Land Management said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Delayed consequences: Hungary is ordered to play in empty stadiums as punishment for its fans’ behavior.
description: UEFA ordered Hungary, which hosted some of the biggest crowds of the Euros in Budapest, to play its next three home matches behind closed doors as punishment for “the discriminatory behaviour of its supporters” during the tournament. The organization also fined the Hungarian soccer federation 100,000 euros ($118,000).
content: UEFA ordered Hungary, which hosted some of the biggest crowds of the Euros in Budapest, to play its next three home matches behind closed doors as punishment for “the discriminatory behaviour of its supporters” during the tournament. The organization also fined the Hungarian soccer federation 100,000 euros ($118,000).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaia Pianigiani
title: Italy thinks it’s coming home, too.
description: Every year is a big soccer year in Italy. When the national league finishes, victorious fans parade through city streets in their cars and mopeds. But it is during the international competitions that the Italian soccer fanaticism takes on a semblance of religious faith.
content: Every year is a big soccer year in Italy. When the national league finishes, victorious fans parade through city streets in their cars and mopeds. But it is during the international competitions that the Italian soccer fanaticism takes on a semblance of religious faith.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: A Better Day Dawns With Pam Tanowitz’s Witty New Dance
description: This choreographer sculpts outdoor space, with her performers creating new dimensions in a Bard SummerScape production.
content: RED HOOK, N.Y. — For a moment or two, Pam Tanowitz may have been regretting the title of her latest dance: “I was waiting for the echo of a better day.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: A Covid Test as Easy as Breathing
description: Scientists have been dreaming of disease-detecting breathalyzers for years. Has the time for the technology finally come?
content: In May, musicians from dozens of countries descended on Rotterdam, the Netherlands, for the Eurovision Song Contest. Over the course of the competition, the performers — clad in sequined dresses, ornate crowns or, in one case, an enormous pair of angel wings — belted and battled it out for their chance at the title.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Miller
title: The Alternating Identities of Shirley Jackson
description: A new collection of letters reveals a self divided between author and woman.
content: THE LETTERS OF SHIRLEY JACKSON Edited by Laurence Jackson Hyman in consultation with Bernice M. Murphy
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Branson and the crew received astronaut wings after their successful trip to space.
description: What you need to know about Richard Branson and crew's space plane flight.
content: Richard Branson finally got his trip to space on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Gopnik
title: Women Who Shaped Modern Photography
description: Female authorship gives meaning to the images in “The New Woman Behind the Camera” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, an inspired and inspiring exhibition.
content: Sometime in the 1930s, the Hungarian photographer Anna Barna shot “Onlooker,” a picture of a boy standing on a chair seen from behind as he peers over a palisade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Novak Djokovic Wins Wimbledon, and His 20th Career Grand Slam Title
description: The world’s best player defeated Matteo Berrettini 6-7 (4), 6-4, 6-4, 6-3, tying him with Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal, and putting him one victory closer to a Golden Slam.
content: Novak Djokovic won the Wimbledon men’s singles championship on Sunday, defeating Matteo Berrettini of Italy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: For Freelancers, Taking Time Off for a Baby Is Risky
description: Family and medical leave is hard to come by for independent workers.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor and Kenneth Chang
title: What will it cost to fly Virgin Galactic to space?
description: A short suborbital jaunt to the edge of space for most people requires having a lot of spare cash on hand, for now.
content: Not long after Richard Branson re-entered Earth’s atmosphere on Sunday, he and other employees of his Virgin Galactic venture boasted that the company would greatly expand opportunities for the general public to travel to space. For the moment, those otherworldly views and feelings of weightlessness will still be held in rarefied air.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Italy’s Victory at Euro 2020 Echoes a Broader Resurgence
description: The national team beat England in the final of the European Championship soccer tournament, and the country wildly celebrated a win that seemed to symbolize renewal after adversity.
content: ROME — The eruption of sheer joy — and car honking and horn blowing and firework exploding and hugging, so much hugging — across Italy on Sunday after its national men’s soccer team defeated England to win the Euro 2020 tournament marked an extraordinary turnaround, not just for a recently beleaguered team, but also for a recently beleaguered country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Italy’s backbone: dependable, inseparable and, at Euro 2020, unbeatable.
description: Italy’s run to the final of Euro 2020 has, in many ways, highlighted a drastic shift in the country’s soccer culture. Roberto Mancini’s team is young, vibrant and adventurous, designed around a slick and technical midfield and imbued with a bright, attacking style.
content: Italy’s run to the final of Euro 2020 has, in many ways, highlighted a drastic shift in the country’s soccer culture. Roberto Mancini’s team is young, vibrant and adventurous, designed around a slick and technical midfield and imbued with a bright, attacking style.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Irene Aldana got a statement win.
description: Amanda Nunes reigns atop the U.F.C. women’s bantamweight division, and it is unlikely that she will release that grip anytime soon based on her recent performances.
content: Amanda Nunes reigns atop the U.F.C. women’s bantamweight division, and it is unlikely that she will release that grip anytime soon based on her recent performances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Stephen Colbert added a dash of comedy as Branson and crew headed toward space.
description: The talk show host, the R&B singer Khalid and others added glitz to an event full of rocket science.
content: In this billionaire space race, slipping the surly bonds of Earth apparently isn’t enough — not without some glitz and a bevy of celebrities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Richard Branson Launches Into Space on Virgin Galactic Flight
description: The 70-year-old British billionaire and crew members of Virgin Galactic launched the commercial space plane Unity from New Mexico, reached the edge of space and landed safely back at the spaceport on Sunday.
content: The 70-year-old British billionaire and crew members of Virgin Galactic launched the commercial space plane Unity from New Mexico, reached the edge of space and landed safely back at the spaceport on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brent McDonald, Danielle Miller, Oren Rosenfeld and David Blumenfeld
title: No Rockets, but Anxiety Persists in Southern Israel
description: The 11-day war between Israel and Hamas ended in May, but for Israelis living and working within range of Gaza, the fear of attack is ever present. We spoke with four people affected by rockets and mortars about their decisions to stay on or leave.
content: The 11-day war between Israel and Hamas ended in May, but for Israelis living and working within range of Gaza, the fear of attack is ever present. We spoke with four people affected by rockets and mortars about their decisions to stay on or leave.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Medical Miracles: When Patients Defy the Odds
description: A hospice physician, a priest and a professor discuss unexpected recoveries. Also: A national building code for high-rises; the 1967 March on the Pentagon vs. the Jan. 6 insurrection.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 11, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, July 11, 2021.
content: An article last Sunday about masks as a signifier of social class misspelled the surname of a public relations strategist who was recently shopping in Hudson Yards. He is Mark Pasetsky, not Pasektsky.
source.name: The New York Times
